Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Situation2: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Story:
I sat on the edge of my bed, phone in hand, feeling the weight of two worlds pressing down on me. My mom and stepdad had been arguing more lately, and I knew they needed me to check in, to ask if everything was okay, to be the steady presence that kept our fragile home from splintering. I could hear my mom’s voice in my head, soft but tired, “Thank you for caring, it means a lot.” 

But my phone buzzed again—a message from my girlfriend. She was devastated, barely able to get out of bed since her brother died last week. She needed me, too. She needed me to listen, to hold her, to be her anchor in a storm that I couldn’t calm. 

I stared at the screen, torn. If I called my mom, I’d be letting my girlfriend down when she needed me most. If I went to my girlfriend, I’d be abandoning my parents, who were counting on me to hold things together. My chest tightened as I tried to figure out who needed me more, and who I’d have to disappoint.
